title: LEARN Topics and Deep-Dives
description: Below are a collection of videos on different topics. Some are introductions and some are deep-dives.

topics.title: Academic Integrity Part 1: Defining the Problem & First Steps
topics.description: Promoting Academic Integrity Part 1: Defining the Problem & First Steps
topics.content: Why do students cheat? Can we convince them not to? Learn how communication and adjustments to assessment strategy can help.
topics.author:
Dr. David Wright, Paul Dagnall, and Dr. Steve Wilhoit
Ryan C. Harris Learning Teaching Center

videos.title: Promoting Academic Integrity - Part 1: Defining the Problem and Taking the First Steps

topics.title: Academic Integrity Part 2: Tools in Isidore
topics.description: Promoting Academic Integrity Part 2: Tools in Isidore
topics.content: The Isidore Learning Management System is loaded with features to steer your students away from cheating. Take advantage of the options that increase the integrity of your assessments.
topics.author:
Dr. David Wright, Paul Dagnall, and Dr. Steve Wilhoit
Ryan C. Harris Learning Teaching Center

videos.title: Promoting Academic Integrity - Part 2: Tools in Isidore

topics.title: Academic Integrity Part 3: Plagiarism & Contract Cheating
topics.description: Promoting Academic Integrity Part 3: Plagiarism & Contract Cheating
topics.content: Plagiarism can be addressed with communication and well crafted assessments. Contract cheating is a problem that often starts with innocent beginnings.
topics.author:
Dr. David Wright, Paul Dagnall, and Dr. Steve Wilhoit
Ryan C. Harris Learning Teaching Center

videos.title: Promoting Academic Integrity - Part 3: Plagiarism and Contract Cheating

topics.title: Taking Attendance in the Blended Classroom
topics.description: Tracking attendance in a blended class can be tricky. See 4 different approaches for recording attendance in a blended environment.
topics.content: Depending on how you are conducting your blended class, you may need to consider creative approaches for taking attendance. In this video, Dr. Julio Quintero and Brenna Seifried present 4 different approaches for taking attendance - some methods even enhance student engagement with the class! However you track attendance, make sure your approach aligns with the University's attendance guidance for the blended semester.
topics.author:
Brenna Seifried and Dr. Julio Quintero
Center for International Programs and Office of Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion

videos.title: Taking Attendance in the Blended Classroom

topics.title: Starting the Semester Off Right
topics.description: First impressions are critical! Listen to two UD instructors share 5 strategies for an engaging first day of class.
topics.content: You only get one chance at that first impression with your students. In this video, the presenters cover five key strategies to help you create an engaging session that will start the semester off right and have your students looking forward to your next class.
topics.author:
Sangita Gosalia and Brenna Seifried
Center for International Programs

topics.title: Blended Teaching: Interview with the Experts
topics.description: Listen to UD's resident experts in blended teaching, Dr. Kellie Schneider and Dr. Ed Mykytka, share their advice for teaching face-to-face and online at the same time.
topics.content: Instructors in the Department of Engineering Management, Systems, and Technology have been delivering their classes in a blended format for almost a decade. In this interview, Dr. Kellie Schneider and Dr. Ed Mykytka share their experiences and advice for instructors who are new to this style of teaching.
topics.author:
Dr. Kellie Schneider and Dr. Ed Mykytka
Department of Engineering Management, Systems, and Technology

videos.title: Blended Teaching: Interview with the Experts

topics.title: Equity in the Blended Classroom
topics.description: Equalize the playing field in a blended class by utilizing resources prepared by Dr. Julio Quintero in the Office of Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion.
topics.content: The pandemic has revealed systemic differences in access to technology and safe learning environments for some students. Small modifications in your teaching in the blended classroom can dramatically help remote students who may not have access to the same technology, same resources, or same learning environments as their on-campus peers. The Office of Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion has prepared resources to help you ensure your class is as inclusive as possible.
topics.author:
Dr. Julio Quintero
Office of Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion

topics.title: Reducing Your Grading Load with Strategic Discussions
topics.description: Learn how to utilize strategic discussion strategies that engage your students and reduce your overall grading load.
topics.content: Are you worried that evaluating and grading online discussions will require a disproportionate amount of your time when planning an online class? In this video, you will discover three instructional design methods - spaced discussions, embedded discussions, and narrowed evaluation - that you can utilize in your course to reduce your grading load while assuring that your students are engaging in robust social learning activities with their peers.
topics.author:
Kent Darr
Office of eLearning

videos.title: Reducing Your Grading Load with Strategic Discussions

topics.title: Reducing Your Grading Load with Model Answers
topics.description: Learn how to reduce your grading time while assuring that your students are completing rigorous learning exercises.
topics.content: Looking for a way to reduce your grading time while assuring that your students are completing rigorous learning exercises? In this video, you'll learn about how you can use the Model Answers feature in Isidore's assignments tool to create a two-part reflective activity that assists students to scaffold themselves up to the next level of expertise so that you can free up time to focus on maximizing your course facilitation time with those who need your help the most.
topics.author:
Kent Darr
Office of eLearning

videos.title: Reducing Your Grading Load with Model Answers

topics.title: Small Group Collaboration in a Blended Class
topics.description: Encourage active learning in your blended classes by using collaboration tools such as murals and Zoom breakout rooms.
topics.content: A blended class presents an opportunity for you to foster creativity and collaboration among your students. Using group collaboration tools, you can split your in-person and online students into small groups to work on contributing to a shared resource, such as a mural or Google Doc. In this video, we will show you how to split your students into small groups and how to set up a Mural for your students to develop. If you need more help on how create and manage breakout rooms in Zoom, please see this video demonstration.
topics.author:
Brian LaDuca and Adrienne Ausdenmoore
Institute of Applied Creativity for Transformation (IACT)

videos.title: Small Group Collaboration in a Blended Class

topics.title: Intrinsic Motivation & Course Communication
topics.description: Incorporating the ARCS method of motivation into your course communications to help increase student intrinsic motivation.
topics.content: Students are more successful in courses where they have a higher level of intrinsic motivation. The ARCS Model of Motivation focuses on Attention, Relevance, Confidence, and Satisfaction. In this video we talk about a very simple way to incorporate ARCS components into your course communication to increase student intrinsic motivation.
topics.author:
Katie Reynolds
Office of eLearning

videos.title: Student Intrinsic Motivation and Course Communication

topics.title: Beat the Boss Monster!
topics.description: Enhance course engagement and learning outcomes using gamification techniques.
topics.content: Games operate off of fairly simple mechanics - beat the boss monster, save the world - yet they offer some of the most engaging and immersive learning experiences on the planet. Join Instructional Designer Kent Darr to discuss three gamification techniques that you can build into your course to enhance engagement and learning outcomes while also preparing students to be a source of common good now and after graduation.
topics.author:
Kent Darr
Office of eLearning
